title: Project
text: You are required to complete a course project. The goal is to practice communicating statistical ideas clearly and critically‚Äîlike you are reporting to colleagues whether a line of work is worth pursuing.

title: Project
text:
Types
Choose one of the following project types:

Research article review
Pick a scholarly research article related to topics in statistical inference (e.g., estimation, testing, likelihood/Bayes, asymptotics, bootstrap, identifiability, robustness, missing data, multiple testing, etc.) _that does not duplicate a topic discussed in class. Your article must be different from your classmates‚Äô choices.
Simulation or data analysis study
Design and carry out a focused study that uses computation to investigate a statistical question. Examples:

Analyze a data set of interest, but go beyond any existing analysis,
Compare procedures (power, bias, coverage, MSE) under realistic departures from assumptions,
Illustrate a theorem/asymptotic approximation with finite-sample behavior,
Replicate and critique an empirical claim from a paper,
Build a small method ‚Äúpipeline‚Äù (e.g., model selection + inference) and evaluate it.

title: Project
text:
Submission

Submit your project topic using the topic submission form by Friday, March 6, 2026.
After the topic deadline, check the posted topic list <To Be Announced> to confirm approval.
Prepare a 15-minute oral presentation (+5 minutes for questions) and a handout for the audience.

title: Project
text:
Presentations and observations

Project presentations will be scheduled near the end of the semester <To Be Announced>.
Each student must observe and assess TWO other presentations (using the Project Assessment Form).
Your project grade is likely to suffer if:

you are not on time for your presentation or observations,
you are not prepared,
you do not observe at least two presentations, and/or
your observer feedback is not significant.

title: Project
text:
Important to keep in mind
Your presentation should be from the perspective that you are reporting to your colleagues why this article/method/result is or is not worth pursuing further.

Your audience is smart, but not specialized in your exact topic. Provide background, definitions, and motivation.
Be critical: clearly state strengths and weaknesses, and what assumptions matter.
You have access to tools (including AI) that were not commonly available a few years ago‚Äîso I will expect more polish and deeper checking.
I may not be an expert in what you present, but I expect you to be, and I will ask probing questions.
Your grade will depend on both:

how clearly you present, and
how well you answer questions.

title: Project
text:
Guidelines

Article review.

Choose a topic not already covered in lecture in essentially the same way.
Prefer papers with enough technical content to support real discussion (not just an application report).
Your job is to explain the idea, demonstrate it on a simple example, and assess it.

Simulation/data study.

Keep the scope appropriate: one sharp question is better than many shallow ones.
Predefine your evaluation metrics (e.g., coverage, power, MSE, false discovery rate).
Use clear plots/tables and report uncertainty when relevant.


General presentation advice:

Keep the big picture in view; don‚Äôt get bogged down in algebra.
Choose one simple example that illustrates the main point.
Look at your audience while speaking; do not read your notes.
Motivate your talk: background, prior work, and why anyone should care.
Discuss pros/cons and failure modes.
Don‚Äôt use too many slides; about one per minute is usually enough.
Don‚Äôt overload slides; prioritize figures/tables over dense text.
Include key formulas/figures directly in your slides rather than making the audience hunt in the paper.
Use your own words. Do not plagiarize.
Practice beforehand. Time yourself.

You will be assessed by your observers and by me using this form:
Project Assessment Form

title: Interesting Articles & Links
text:
This page collects optional articles, essays, videos, and interactive resources that connect probability, statistics, and data science to real applications, historical context, or broader ideas.

Statistical Inference and Data Science

The Lady Tasting Tea

A famous experiment conducted by Ronald Fisher to test whether a woman could distinguish between tea poured before or after milk
This experiment is often cited as an example of a randomized controlled trial and the basis for Fisher‚Äôs exact test

Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures

An influential paper by Leo Breiman that discusses the differences between traditional statistical modeling and algorithmic modeling in data science
Breiman argues that the algorithmic modeling culture, which focuses on predictive accuracy, is often more effective than the traditional statistical modeling culture, which focuses on inference and understanding

As Forecasts Go, You Can Bet on Monte Carlo

An article from the Wall Street Journal that discusses the use of Monte Carlo simulations in financial forecasting and risk management
The article highlights how Monte Carlo methods can help quantify uncertainty and improve decision-making in finance




Software and Libraries

qmcpy.org: A Python Library for Quasi-Monte Carlo Methods

A Python library for quasi-Monte Carlo methods, which are used to improve the efficiency of numerical integration and simulation

Rankings of Computer Languages

A ranking of programming languages based on their popularity and usage in the industry
Statistical questions include: What are the errors in the percentages? What is the significance of a change in rank?

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
text: This course uses a Git repository that includes submodules (shared libraries pulled in as separate Git repos). To get everything working, you must clone the repo and initialize the submodules.

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: Important: do not push to the course repository
text:
Important: do not push to the course repository
Students should assume the course repository is read-only:

Do not try to push changes to the course repo.
If you see errors like ‚Äúpermission denied‚Äù when pushing, that is expected.

You will not submit homework via Git. Git is used only to:

Obtain and update course materials
Experiment with class notebooks

When experimenting, consider working in copies of notebooks or in a separate directory so updates pull cleanly


If you want an online backup of your personal work, you may optionally use your own private repository or a fork (see below).

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
text:
Step 0: Prerequisites
You need:

Git installed
A way to authenticate with GitHub (either SSH or HTTPS)

Your instructor will provide the course repo URL. It looks like one of these:

SSH: git@github.com:ORG/MATHXXXSpring20YY.git
HTTPS: https://github.com/ORG/MATHXXXSpring20YY.git

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: Step 1: Clone the course repo with submodules
text:
Step 1: Clone the course repo with submodules
Choose one of the following.

Option A (recommended): clone with submodules in one step
Replace REPO_URL with the URL you were given.
git clone --recurse-submodules REPO_URL


Option B: clone first, then fetch submodules
git clone REPO_URL
cd MATHXXXSpring20YY
git submodule update --init --recursive

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: Step 2: Verify you have the submodule content
text:
Step 2: Verify you have the submodule content
From inside the course repo:
git submodule status
You should see one or more lines showing submodules and commit hashes. If you see errors or blank output, run:
git submodule update --init --recursive

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: Keeping your local copy updated during the semester
text:
Keeping your local copy updated during the semester
Do this whenever your instructor says ‚Äúpull the latest changes.‚Äù
From inside the course repo:
git pull --ff-only
git submodule update --init --recursive
That second command is important: it updates submodules to the versions pinned by the course repo.

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: If you already made local changes
text:
If you already made local changes
If git pull --ff-only fails, it usually means you have local commits or uncommitted changes.
Check what changed:
git status

If you only changed files you don‚Äôt care about (quick reset)
git reset --hard
git pull --ff-only
git submodule update --init --recursive


If you want to keep your work
Commit your changes first so they are safely recorded locally.
git add -A
git commit -m "My work"
git pull --ff-only
git submodule update --init --recursive
If the pull still fails, you may need to resolve a merge conflict (ask for help).

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
section: Optional: fork workflow (push only to your own fork)
text:
Optional: fork workflow (push only to your own fork)
Use this only if you want to push your work to GitHub for backup/versioning.

One-time setup (fork + clone)

Fork the course repo on GitHub into your own GitHub account.
Clone your fork (not the instructor repo) with submodules.

Replace FORK_URL with your fork‚Äôs URL:
git clone --recurse-submodules FORK_URL
cd MATHXXXSpring20YY

Add the instructor repo as upstream so you can pull course updates.

Replace UPSTREAM_URL with the instructor repo URL:
git remote add upstream UPSTREAM_URL
git remote -v


Getting updates from the instructor (sync upstream ‚Üí your fork)
From inside your cloned fork:
git fetch upstream
git checkout main
git merge --ff-only upstream/main
git submodule update --init --recursive
git push
If the course repo uses a branch other than main (e.g., master), replace main above accordingly.

title: Git setup: clone the course repo and keep it updated
text:
Common issues and fixes

‚Äúfatal: not a git repository‚Äù
You‚Äôre not inside the course repo folder. Change into it:
cd MATHXXXSpring20YY


‚ÄúPermission denied (publickey)‚Äù (SSH)
You‚Äôre using an SSH URL but your SSH key isn‚Äôt set up for GitHub. Use the HTTPS URL instead, or configure SSH.


Submodule errors after pulling
Re-run the submodule update:
git submodule update --init --recursive


You accidentally cloned without submodules
From inside the repo:
git submodule update --init --recursive


Avoid updating submodules beyond what the instructor pinned
Students should not run git submodule update --remote unless explicitly instructed.

title: Policies
section: Academic Integrity, Technology, and AI Usage
text:
Academic Integrity, Technology, and AI Usage
You are encouraged to use technology, including AI tools like ChatGPT, to explore ideas and complete assignments or projects, as long as you understand the work and can explain it yourself. On tests and the final exam, no technology or AI will be allowed unless I say otherwise. Always use these tools to support your learning, not to replace it, and give credit if they meaningfully contribute to your work.
Students are expected to uphold the highest standards of honesty in their academic work, in accordance with Illinois Tech‚Äôs Code of Academic Honesty.

Permitted Use

Assignments & Projects: You are encouraged to use technology and AI tools to assist in problem-solving, exploring concepts, and checking work.
You must critically evaluate AI-generated content for accuracy, completeness, and clarity.
You are responsible for understanding and being able to explain any work produced with technological assistance.



Prohibited Use

Tests & Final Exam: No technology, AI tools, or external resources may be used unless explicitly allowed by the instructor.
Submitting AI-generated or technological outputs without personal understanding is prohibited and will be treated as a violation.



Citations & Transparency
If you use AI tools, software, or other external resources in a way that significantly shapes your work, you must acknowledge it (e.g., ‚ÄúApproach suggested by ChatGPT‚Äù).


Consequences
Violations will be handled according to Illinois Tech‚Äôs Code of Academic Honesty.
